titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Catherine Viviano Gallery records, 1930-1990, bulk 1949-1978, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Joy Weiner

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Joy Weiner on September 27, 2010

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: The records of the Catherine Viviano Gallery measure 11.6 linear feet and date from 1930-1990, with the bulk of the materials dating from 1949-1978. Established in New York City in 1949, the gallery specialized in contemporary painting and sculpture primarily by American and European artists. The collection consists of artists' files; correspondence with artists, collectors, dealers, museum directors, curators, and publishers; business records; printed material; and photographs of artwork and artists. Also included are records relating to Catherine Viviano's activities as a private dealer and consultant after she closed the gallery in 1970.
did.langmaterial: Some records are in French, German, Italian, Portuguese, and Spanish.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Catherine Viviano Gallery records were donated in 2003 on behalf of Margaret Viviano, Catherine Viviano's sister, by her grandnephew, Peter C. Salerno, who had Power of Attorney for Margaret Viviano.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Among the other resources relating to Catherine Viviano Gallery in the Archives of American Art are the Kay Sage papers, 1925-circa 1985, bulk 1950-1965.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Joy Weiner in 2010.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Catherine Viviano Gallery records, 1930-1990, bulk 1949-1978. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Catherine Viviano Gallery records records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Catherine Viviano (1889-1992) opened her gallery in 1949 on 42 East 57th Street in New York City. Specializing in contemporary American paintings and sculpture, the gallery featured younger American and European artists, e.g., Robert Broderson, Carlyle Brown, Jan Cox, Joseph Glasco, Peter Lanyon, Manabu Mabe, César Manrique, Bernard Perlin, Joseph Rollo, Bernard Rosenthal, and Kay Sage, among others. The gallery was also notable for introducing the work of Italian artists, who had been cut off from the American art scene during World War II, including Afro Basaldella and his brother Mirko Basaldella, Renato Birolli, Leonardo Cremonini, and Luciano Minguzzi.

Born in Italy in 1899 and raised in Chicago, Catherine Viviano came to New York in the early 1930's to work at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, where she remained for sixteen years before founding the Catherine Viviano Gallery.
In 1970, Catherine Viviano closed the gallery, though she continued to work from her home as an art dealer and consultant. She died of a stroke at the age of ninety-two in 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The records of the Catherine Viviano Gallery measure 11.6 linear feet and date from 1930-1990, with the bulk of the materials dating from 1949-1978. Established in New York City in 1949, the gallery specialized in contemporary painting and sculpture primarily by American and European artists. The collection consists of artists' files; correspondence with artists, collectors, dealers, museum directors, curators, and publishers; business records; printed material; and photographs of artwork and artists. Also included are records relating to Catherine Viviano's activities as a private dealer and consultant after she closed the gallery in 1970.

Artists' files include biographical material; artists' statements; correspondence; sales and expense reports; lists and notes; guest lists; writings by others; receipts, invoices, and statements; printed material, including press releases, exhibition announcements, brochures, catalogues, clippings; and photographs of artwork and artists. Included are extensive files on Afro Basaldella, Renato Birolli, Robert Broderson, Anselmo Franesconi, Joseph Glasco, Manabu Mabe, César Manrique, Luciano Minguzzi, Ennio Morlotti, Bernard Perlin, Daniel Rice, and Bernard Rosenthal. There are also files on Jan Cox, Kay Sage, and Kazuo Wakabayashi.

Correspondence comprises the largest series in the collection and consists of general correspondence; correspondence with museums, galleries, and art-related institutions in the United States; and correspondence with museums, galleries, and art-related institutions abroad. Letters focus on routine business matters, e.g., appraisals and sales, acquisitions, and organizing exhibitions at the Catherine Viviano Gallery and other venues.

General correspondence includes letters between Catherine Viviano and artists and their family members. Among the correspondents are: Mary Callery, Bernard Chaet, Piero and Virginia Dorazio, Jean Dubuffet, Dallas Ernst, Karl Fortress, Alberto Giacometti, Henry Sage Goodwin, Morris Graves, José Guerrero, Earle Ludgin, Joan Miro, Alfonso Ossorio, Dorothea Tanning, Stuyvesant Van Veen, Adja Yunkers and his wife, Dore Ashton, among others. Also found is Viviano's correspondence with clients, many of whom were prominent collectors, e.g., Richard Brown Baker, Carl and Joan Fisher, Lawrence and Barbara Fleischman, Joseph Hirschhorn, Marc Moyens, Vincent Price, Joseph Pulitzer, Jr., Nelson Rockefeller, Stanley Seeger, and Frederick and Dorothy Zimmerman. Of interest, are letters from Elizabeth Bishop inquiring about the purchase of a work of art from the gallery. Included are letters from art historians, museum directors, curators, representatives at other art-related institutions, and publishers including Walter Bareiss, Walter Barker, Dominque De Menil, Valentine Dudensing, William Eisendrath, S. Lane Faison, Emily Genauer, Bertram Goodhue, Erhard and Barbara Göpel, James Laughlin, Porter McCray, Abram Lerner, Doris Meltzer, Stephen Robson Miller, John Bernard Myers, Perry Rathbone, Belle Krasne Ribicoff, Meyer Shapiro, George Stout, and Curt Valentin.

Correspondence with museums, galleries, and art-related institutions in the United States contains letters between Viviano and museum directors, curators, dealers, artists, and collectors pertaining to loans, shipping and delivery of artwork, appraisals and sales, and acquisitions. Files include substantive correspondence with the American Academy of Arts and Letters, American Federation of the Arts, Art Institute of Chicago, Arts Club of Chicago, the Barnes Foundation, Bristol Art Museum, Brooklyn Museum, Bundy Art Gallery, Carnegie Institute, City Art Museum of St. Louis, Cleveland Museum of Art, Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center, Dallas Museum of Fine Arts, Denver Art Museum, Des Moines Art Center, Detroit Institute of Arts, Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University, Hirschhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Institute of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles County Art Museum, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Museum of Fine Arts of Houston, Museum of Modern Art, Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Philadelphia Art Alliance, Santa Barbara Museum of Art, University of Nebraska Art Galleries, University of Virginia, Mary Washington College, Wadsworth Atheneum, Walker Art Center, William Rockhill Nelson Gallery of Art, Atkins Museum of the Fine Arts, World House Gallery, and Yale University Art Library.

Correspondence with museums, galleries, and art-related institutions abroad primarily concerns the lending of artwork for exhibitions, acquisition and sales; also included are letters requesting biographical information on artists. Letters between Catherine Viviano and representatives of Max Beckmann Gesellschaft Archiv and Galerie Gunther Franke contain provenance-related information on Beckmann's work.

Business records document the routine business operations of the gallery. Printed material includes an incomplete run of Catherine Viviano Gallery exhibition catalogues; invitations and announcements from other galleries and institutions; and miscellaneous printed material.
Photographs include three images of miscellaneous artwork used for art reference.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Records are generally arranged by material type and in chronological order thereafter. Artists' files and correspondence files are arranged in alphabetical order and materials within the folders are arranged chronologically
The collection is arranged as 5 series:

controlaccess.head: Names and Subject Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following terms:

controlaccess.corpname: American Academy of Arts and Letters
City Art Museum of St. Louis
Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.)
Museum of Modern Art (New York, N.Y.)
Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
William Rockhill Nelson Gallery of Art and Mary Atkins Museum of Fine Arts
Yale University. Art and Architecture Library

scopecontent.p: Artists' files include: biographical material; correspondence; sales of artwork; guest lists; notes and writings; business-related material; printed matter, e.g., exhibition catalogues, brochures, clippings, press releases, reproductions; and photographs of artwork and artists.

Biographical material contains curriculum vitae and artists' statements. Correspondence consists of letters, postcards, greeting cards, and telegrams between Viviano and artists, their family members, collectors, dealers, museum representatives, art historians, and others. Correspondence, for the most part, concerns sales, market valuations, and scheduling of exhibitions. Letters reflect the personal relationships that Viviano developed with many of the gallery's artists and collectors. Correspondence also includes business-related materials such as invoices, shipping receipts and statements, invoices, sales and expense reports, and miscellaneous legal claims.

There are substantive files on Renato Birolli, Robert Broderson, Joseph Glasco, Manabu Mabe, César Manrique, Luciano Minguzzi, Ennio Morlotti, Bernard Perlin, Daniel Rice, and Bernard Rosenthal. Miscellaneous artists' files include biographical materials, checklists, consignment sale slips from the Grand Street Settlement, a typescript on Max Beckmann, notes, lists, and exhibition catalogues.

arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by artist and materials within the folders are in chronological order. Artists' files for which numerous documents are found are further divided by type of material.

scopecontent.p: This series contains the gallery's general correspondence with artists, their family members, dealers, collectors, prospective clients, art historians, curators, museum directors, and others; correspondence with museums, galleries, and art-related institutions in the United States; and correspondence with museums, galleries, and art-related institutions abroad.
Included with the correspondence are loan forms, consignment agreements, invoices, shipping receipts, printed materials, annotated exhibition catalogues, and photographs of artwork.

list.item: 2.2: Correspondence with Museums, Galleries, and Art-Related Institutions, United States, 1950-1984
2.3: Correspondence with Museums, Galleries, and Art-Related Institutions Abroad, 1951-1975

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Viviano's correspondence with artists and their family members, historians, clients, publishers, and individuals at museums, galleries, and non-profit arts organizations. Included are letters from Margaret Viviano, who worked closely with her sister Catherine in the gallery. There are files of Catherine Viviano's scattered correspondence, some of it personal. Materials include carbon copies, drafts, postcards, telegrams, and photographs of artwork. Also found are illustrated letters, holiday and greeting cards, many with original artwork.

Letters include detailed information on the gallery's general operations: acquisitions, sales, loans, shipping and delivery of artwork, insurance claims, and requests for biographical material on artists and permission to reproduce artwork. Letters also provide an overview of Viviano's efforts in promoting artists, developing relationships with clients and collectors, and organizing exhibitions. Among the artists frequently referred to in the correspondence are Afro and Mirko Basaldella, Max Beckmann, Renato Birolli, Robert Broderson, Leonardo Cremonini, Joseph Glasco, Luciano Minguzzi, Bernard Perlin, Faustus Pirandello, Bernard Rosenthal, and Kay Sage.

The bulk of the correspondence with artists represented by the gallery is found in the artists' files. Some of the names in general correspondence can also be found in correspondence with galleries, museums, and art-related institutions in the United States and abroad.

Correspondence with Museums, Galleries, and Art-Related Institutions, United States, 1950-1984

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of the gallery's letters to representatives of museums, dealers, independent schools, universities, colleges, and non-for-profit institutions. Subjects discussed are market valuations and appraisals; acquisitions and sales; and loans of artwork for exhibitions.

Correspondence also includes memoranda, consignment agreements, loan forms, shipping and receipt of objects forms, lists of artwork with valuations and sale prices, insurance claim forms, ledger pages with sale prices of artwork, guest lists, press releases, printed material, clippings, exhibition announcements, invitations, and photographs of artwork.

Viviano maintained an ongoing correspondence with numerous public and university museums, galleries, and arts organizations in the United States. Of particular note, the correspondence with the Museum of Modern Art's (New York) Department of Circulating Exhibitions and Junior Council provides a rich source of information on acquisitions and sales from the 1950's through 1960's. Also found is correspondence pertaining to Catherine Viviano's involvement in professional associations.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically, by institution, and the materials within the folders are in chronological order.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains letters between Catherine Viviano and museum directors, gallery owners, curators, publishers, and individuals affiliated with arts organizations in Europe, Brazil, Canada, and Mexico. Included in the correspondence are loan forms, shipping receipts, bank slips, invoices, auction orders, insurance claims, press releases, and printed material. Correspondence concerns sales and appraisals; exhibition itineraries; and requests for biographical information.

Among the artists frequently cited in the correspondence are: Afro Basaldella, Joseph Glasco, Peter Lanyon, Luciano Minguzzi, Bernard Perlin, Bernard Rosenthal, and Kay Sage. Correspondence with Galerie Gunter Franke and Max Beckmann Gesellschaft Archiv provides sales information and detailed exhibition histories for individual works of art by Beckmann.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by institution, and letters within the folder are in chronological order.

University of London, Courtauld Institute of Art, 1951, undated

scopecontent.p: This series documents Catherine Viviano's business transactions as a dealer and after the gallery closed, as a freelance art consultant. Files include ledgers, a notebook of sales and loose pages of sales, check registers, correspondence, notes, and scattered business and legal files.

Ledgers record cash receipts, cash disbursements, accounts receivable, accounts payable, Catherine Viviano's personal expenses, sales by artists, and a general journal. Also found are a notebook and loose ledger pages of sales and payments to artists, including a list of the artwork sold at the gallery's first exhibition. Generally, the titles of artwork are omitted in the sales records.

Included are Catherine Viviano's letters to the managing agent for the 42 East 57th Street building pertaining to the renewal of the lease and requests for routine repairs in the gallery. Miscellaneous business records contain shipping instructions and a receipt for delivery of artwork. Business records can also be found in artists' files, correspondence, and printed material.

Legal files include a suit for non-payment of art brought by Catherine Viviano against a client and an affidavit with respect to character for Peter C. Salerno for his admission to the State Bar of New York.

arrangement.p: Ledgers and a notebook of sales of artwork to individuals were disbound by the processor. The records are arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.p: Printed material houses catalogues of solo and group shows, announcements, invitations, brochures of exhibitions held at the Catherine Viviano Gallery and other venues. Files also contain miscellaneous printed material: press releases, artist's statement, biographical matter, clipping, an art periodical, and a monograph.

Included are catalogues of one-man shows for artists that Viviano represented over the years: Max Beckmann, Peter Lanyon, Joseph Glasco, Bernard Perlin, Dan Rice, Felix Ruvolo, Kay Sage, and Emilio Vedova. There is a 1973 catalogue of Max Beckmann's paintings, sculptures, drawings, and watercolors, which was organized by Catherine Viviano in her role as an independent dealer. Exhibition catalogs can also be found in Series 1: Artists' Files and Series 2: Correspondence.

arrangement.p: The materials within the folders are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Exhibition Announcements, Invitations, and Brochures (other venues), 1958-1979, undated

scopecontent.p: This series houses photographs of miscellaneous artwork used for art reference.
Photographs can also be found in Series 1: Artists' Files and Series 2: Correspondence.
